What is Verus Vault, and how does it protect funds on a VerusID?

Verus Vault is a feature of the Verus ecosystem that provides an additional layer of security to protect funds on a VerusID. With Verus Vault, you can lock your VerusID, which prevents anyone, including the owner of the private key, from spending funds associated with that identity until it is unlocked. This means that even if your private key is stolen, the thief will not be able to access your funds.

While the VerusID is locked, you can still stake your funds on the Verus network and earn rewards. You can also continue to receive funds on that identity. However, to spend or access the funds, you will need to unlock the VerusID, which will trigger a waiting period before the funds can be accessed.

To enable Verus Vault, you need to have at least one primary identity and one revocation/recovery ID configured. The revocation and recovery authority identities can still revoke and recover the locked VerusID, which provides an additional layer of security.

Verus Vault is particularly useful in preventing the "5 dollar wrench attack," where an attacker steals your private key by physical means. With Verus Vault, you can set a delay time, such as 24 hours, before the funds can be accessed after unlocking. This allows you or a third-party service to detect and respond to unauthorized unlock attempts.

In addition to protecting funds, Verus Vault also provides security for IDs and NFTs, as well as time locks for other purposes, such as vesting schedules, trusts, and inheritance. Overall, Verus Vault provides a decentralized solution for protecting and recovering funds, preserving your assets and generational blockchain wealth without the need for a traditional bank.
